articles.headline: Chain of Avoidable Errors Cited in Koran Burning
articles.snippet: American and Afghan officials say the incineration of Korans could have been headed off at several points.
articles.abstract: American and Afghan officials say the incineration of Korans could have been headed off at several points.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — American and Afghan officials investigating the Koran-burning episode that has brought relations between the countries to a new low say that the destruction could have been headed off at several points along a chain of mishaps, poor judgments and ignored procedures, according to interviews over the past week.

articles.headline: For iRobot, the Future Is Getting Closer
articles.snippet: iRobot has sold millions of Roomba vacuum cleaners, and its bomb disposal robots protect soldiers. Now, it is using video and computing advances to create robots that can handle more duties.
articles.abstract: iRobot has sold millions of Roomba vacuum cleaners, and its bomb disposal robots protect soldiers. Now, it is using video and computing advances to create robots that can handle more duties.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEDFORD, Mass. — Ever since Rosey the Robot took care of “The Jetsons” in the early 1960s, the promise of robots making everyday life easier has been a bit of a tease.

articles.headline: At Angie’s List, the Reviews Are Real (So Is Angie)
articles.snippet: At a time when everyone wants information for free, Angie’s List, which features user-generated reviews of services, charges for access. Yet something about its business model is working.
articles.abstract: At a time when everyone wants information for free, Angie’s List, which features user-generated reviews of services, charges for access. Yet something about its business model is working.
articles.lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS

articles.headline: Apps Seek to Help Phone Users Track Data
articles.snippet: As unlimited data plans fade away, services and applications are being designed to help users manage their consumption.
articles.abstract: As unlimited data plans fade away, services and applications are being designed to help users manage their consumption.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Cellphone carriers are forcing customers to think about how much data they are slurping up as they watch YouTube and stream music from Pandora. In the United States, customers with unlimited plans who use a lot of data have found themselves forced into a network slow lane.

articles.headline: Builders of Casino Empire Split, and the Bitter Accusations Fly
articles.snippet: In one of the gambling industry’s most rancorous public feuds, Stephen A. Wynn and Kazuo Okada are accusing one another of making payments meant to curry favor from public officials.
articles.abstract: In one of the gambling industry’s most rancorous public feuds, Stephen A. Wynn and Kazuo Okada are accusing one another of making payments meant to curry favor from public officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: MACAO — For more than a decade, they were the odd couple of gambling.

articles.headline: Accord Reached Settling Lawsuit Over BP Oil Spill
articles.snippet: BP agreed with the lawyers for businesses and individuals affected by the 2010 oil spill to pay $7.8 billion in claims, but the federal government, the largest plaintiff, was not a party to the settlement.
articles.abstract: BP agreed with the lawyers for businesses and individuals affected by the 2010 oil spill to pay $7.8 billion in claims, but the federal government, the largest plaintiff, was not a party to the settlement.
articles.lead_paragraph: BP and the lawyers for plaintiffs in the trial over the 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico have agreed to settle their case.

articles.headline: Bearing Witness in Syria: A Correspondent’s Last Days
articles.snippet: Tyler Hicks, a photographer for The New York Times, recounted his trip into Syria last month with Anthony Shadid, a Times correspondent who died during the assignment.
articles.abstract: Tyler Hicks, a photographer for The New York Times, recounted his trip into Syria last month with Anthony Shadid, a Times correspondent who died during the assignment.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was damp and cold as Anthony Shadid and I crossed in darkness over the barbed-wire fence that separated Turkey from Syria last month. We were also crossing from peace into war, into the bloodiest conflict of the Arab Spring, exploding just up the rocky and sparsely wooded mountain we had to climb once inside.

articles.headline: Mission Control, Built for Cities
articles.snippet: I.B.M. has designed a new operations center for the city of Rio de Janeiro, coordinating all kinds of functions under one roof. The company hopes the project will lead to a huge worldwide business.
articles.abstract: I.B.M. has designed a new operations center for the city of Rio de Janeiro, coordinating all kinds of functions under one roof. The company hopes the project will lead to a huge worldwide business.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOT far from Copacabana Beach here is a control room that looks straight out of NASA.

articles.headline: Trying to Feel Like a Million Bucks, Too
articles.snippet: Many of the business world’s titans stay in shape at Sitaras Fitness, a Midtown Manhattan gym that is the brainchild of a bodybuilder. He — and his software — track the members’ progress.
articles.abstract: Many of the business world’s titans stay in shape at Sitaras Fitness, a Midtown Manhattan gym that is the brainchild of a bodybuilder. He — and his software — track the members’ progress.
articles.lead_paragraph: THERE’S a place on East 58th Street in Manhattan, with no outdoor sign, where George Soros, David Geffen, Paul Volcker, Jules Kroll and other big names in the business and financial world are regulars.

articles.headline: 0.2% Interest? You Bet We’ll Complain
articles.snippet: Rock-bottom interest rates shore up big banks, but they punish savers — and look likely to keep doing so for quite some time.
articles.abstract: Rock-bottom interest rates shore up big banks, but they punish savers — and look likely to keep doing so for quite some time.
articles.lead_paragraph: STOP your bellyaching.

articles.headline: U.S. Backers of Israel Pressure Obama Over Policy on Iran
articles.snippet: From Congress to a major conference of American Jews and other supporters of Israel, President Obama is being buffeted by calls for a more aggressive posture toward Tehran.
articles.abstract: From Congress to a major conference of American Jews and other supporters of Israel, President Obama is being buffeted by calls for a more aggressive posture toward Tehran.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the eve of a crucial visit to the White House by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, that country’s most powerful American advocates are mounting an extraordinary public campaign to pressure President Obama into hardening American policy toward Iran over its nuclear program.

articles.headline: In a Flood Tide of Digital Data, an Ark Full of Books
articles.snippet: As society embraces all forms of digital entertainment, a latter-day Noah is looking the other way. Brewster Kahle, who runs the Internet Archive, a nonprofit, hopes to collect one copy of every book.
articles.abstract: As society embraces all forms of digital entertainment, a latter-day Noah is looking the other way. Brewster Kahle, who runs the Internet Archive, a nonprofit, hopes to collect one copy of every book.
articles.lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Calif. — In a wooden warehouse in this industrial suburb, the 20th century is being stored in case of digital disaster.

articles.headline: From ‘Nominal Catholic’ to Clarion of Faith
articles.snippet: Over the past two decades, Rick Santorum has undergone a religious transformation that is now spurring a national conversation about faith in the public sphere.
articles.abstract: Over the past two decades, Rick Santorum has undergone a religious transformation that is now spurring a national conversation about faith in the public sphere.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREAT FALLS, Va. — Rick Santorum was, in his own words, a “nominal Catholic” when he met Karen Garver, a neonatal nurse and law student, in 1988. As they made plans to marry and he decided to enter politics, she sent him to her father for advice.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: Romney Traces Obama’s Path on Delegates
articles.snippet: Having failed to secure the nomination in the first two months of voting, Mitt Romney is turning, his aides say, to a methodical delegate accumulation similar to President Obama’s 2008 campaign.
articles.abstract: Having failed to secure the nomination in the first two months of voting, Mitt Romney is turning, his aides say, to a methodical delegate accumulation similar to President Obama’s 2008 campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The first phase of the 2012 Republican presidential campaign, ending with the 10 states that vote this week on Super Tuesday, has been about money and message. The next several months will be about maps and math.

articles.headline: Putin Wins, but Opposition Keeps Pressing
articles.snippet: Vladimir V. Putin’s widely expected victory in Russia’s presidential election set up a confrontation with an opposition movement that has rallied tens of thousands of protesters.
articles.abstract: Vladimir V. Putin’s widely expected victory in Russia’s presidential election set up a confrontation with an opposition movement that has rallied tens of thousands of protesters.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russian voters overwhelmingly granted Vladimir V. Putin a six-year term as president on Sunday, a widely expected outcome that set the stage for a far more suspenseful post-election confrontation between the freshly emboldened leader and an opposition movement that has repeatedly rallied tens of thousands of protesters.

articles.headline: ‘Loose Talk of War’ Only Helps Iran, President Says
articles.snippet: In a speech to a pro-Israel lobbying group, President Obama gave a forceful defense of his commitment to Israel’s security, taking on criticism from his Republican rivals.
articles.abstract: In a speech to a pro-Israel lobbying group, President Obama gave a forceful defense of his commitment to Israel’s security, taking on criticism from his Republican rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Republicans on the campaign trail ramped up their support for Israel in a possible military strike on Iran, President Obama used a speech before a pro-Israel lobbying group on Sunday to warn against the “loose talk of war” that could serve to speed Iran toward a nuclear weapon.

articles.headline: Foreign Investment in Europe Starts Anew
articles.snippet: As the clamor over the debt crisis subsides somewhat, multinational corporations are picking their spots in Europe for the day the economy turns the corner.
articles.abstract: As the clamor over the debt crisis subsides somewhat, multinational corporations are picking their spots in Europe for the day the economy turns the corner.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Last summer, as the mounting European debt crisis was forcing many businesses in the region to scale back, the multinational Dow Chemical made a seemingly contrarian move: rather than hunker down, it doubled down.

articles.headline: Deepwater Oil Drilling Picks Up Again as BP Disaster Fades
articles.snippet: After a yearlong oil drilling moratorium, BP and other companies have intensified exploration and production in the Gulf of Mexico, and drilling will soon expand to Mexican and Cuban waters.
articles.abstract: After a yearlong oil drilling moratorium, BP and other companies have intensified exploration and production in the Gulf of Mexico, and drilling will soon expand to Mexican and Cuban waters.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Nearly two years after an explosion on an oil platform killed 11 workers and sent millions of gallons of oil gushing into the Gulf of Mexico, deepwater drilling has regained momentum in the gulf and is spreading around the world.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and John M. Broder

articles.headline: The Bright Side of Being Hacked
articles.snippet: One benefit of an attack by a group like Anonymous: it can gird a company against more serious online espionage.
articles.abstract: One benefit of an attack by a group like Anonymous: it can gird a company against more serious online espionage.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Hackers operating under the banner Anonymous have been poking a finger in the eye of one private company after another for two years now.
articles.byline: By Somini Sengupta and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: DVRs and Streaming Prompt a Shift in the Top-Rated TV Shows
articles.snippet: Viewers who watch prime-time television days later are becoming an essential factor in determining a show’s popularity.
articles.abstract: Viewers who watch prime-time television days later are becoming an essential factor in determining a show’s popularity.
articles.lead_paragraph: For almost a decade, identifying the most popular show on television has been easy: “American Idol,” case closed.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: Finding Your Book Interrupted ... By the Tablet You Read It On
articles.snippet: With diversions like e-mail, Twitter, YouTube and games a few taps away, the book-reading experience on a tablet is more like a 21st-century cacophony than a traditional solitary activity.
articles.abstract: With diversions like e-mail, Twitter, YouTube and games a few taps away, the book-reading experience on a tablet is more like a 21st-century cacophony than a traditional solitary activity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Can you concentrate on Flaubert when Facebook is only a swipe away, or give your true devotion to Mr. Darcy while Twitter beckons?
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: News Corp. Staving Off a Scandal
articles.snippet: Investors have been cheering the possibility that the negative news in Britain could prompt the company to spin off its newspapers.
articles.abstract: Investors have been cheering the possibility that the negative news in Britain could prompt the company to spin off its newspapers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Monday, British investigators said that News Corporation’s British tabloid, The Sun, had participated in widespread bribery to “a network of corrupted officials.”

articles.headline: Slum Dwellers Are Defying Brazil’s Grand Design for Olympics
articles.snippet: Ambitious development plans for the 2016 Summer Olympics, as well as the 2014 soccer World Cup, involve large-scale evictions from numerous slums, whose residents are refusing to leave.
articles.abstract: Ambitious development plans for the 2016 Summer Olympics, as well as the 2014 soccer World Cup, involve large-scale evictions from numerous slums, whose residents are refusing to leave.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — It was supposed to be a triumphant moment for Brazil.

articles.headline: Limbaugh Advertisers Flee Show Amid Storm
articles.snippet: Despite an apology on Saturday, Rush Limbaugh is facing a loss of advertisers unnerved by growing criticism of his comments about a Georgetown University student last week.
articles.abstract: Despite an apology on Saturday, Rush Limbaugh is facing a loss of advertisers unnerved by growing criticism of his comments about a Georgetown University student last week.
articles.lead_paragraph: Emboldened by Rush Limbaugh’s public apology over the weekend to a law school student whom he had called a “slut” and a “prostitute,” critics of the radio talk show host are intensifying their online campaign against his advertisers.

articles.headline: Apple’s Job Creation Data Spurs an Economic Debate
articles.snippet: In an effort to show its benefit to the American job market, Apple on Friday published the results of a study it commissioned saying that it had “created or supported” 514,000 American jobs.
articles.abstract: In an effort to show its benefit to the American job market, Apple on Friday published the results of a study it commissioned saying that it had “created or supported” 514,000 American jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple has made its first attempt to quantify how many American jobs can be credited to the sale of its iPads and other products, a group that includes the Apple engineers who design the devices and the drivers who deliver them — even the people who build the trucks that get them there.

articles.headline: Before Super Tuesday, Big Names Rally to Romney
articles.snippet: Two leading fiscal conservatives, Representative Eric Cantor and Senator Tom Coburn, declared their loyalties for the first time on Sunday, with John Ashcroft set to join the team Monday.
articles.abstract: Two leading fiscal conservatives, Representative Eric Cantor and Senator Tom Coburn, declared their loyalties for the first time on Sunday, with John Ashcroft set to join the team Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — A reluctant Republican Party is increasingly showing signs of rallying around Mitt Romney in the presidential race, with leading members of Congress and influential conservatives signaling that a coast-to-coast burst of voting on Super Tuesday should mark a moment to start concentrating on defeating President Obama.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: As New iPad Debut Nears, Some See Decline of PCs
articles.snippet: The iPad, considered a side business for Apple when it was introduced in 2010, accounted for $9.15 billion in revenue in the holiday quarter, about 20 percent of Apple’s total revenue.
articles.abstract: The iPad, considered a side business for Apple when it was introduced in 2010, accounted for $9.15 billion in revenue in the holiday quarter, about 20 percent of Apple’s total revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: The chief executive of Apple, Timothy D. Cook, has a prediction: the day will come when tablet devices like the Apple iPad outsell traditional personal computers.
